title: Psalms Chapter 74 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 74 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 74 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 74.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74:1, why does the psalmist ask God if He has cast them off?
options: Because of anger against the sheep of His pasture
Because of their sins
Because of their enemies' power
Because of famine in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Because of anger against the sheep of His pasture
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:1 says, 'O God, why hast thou cast us off for ever? why doth thine anger smoke against the sheep of thy pasture?'. The psalmist asks because God's anger is against His people.

questions.question: What does Psalms 74:2 ask God to remember?
options: Thy congregation which Thou hast purchased of old
The enemies who destroyed the sanctuary
The mighty rivers and floods
The summer and winter seasons
questions.correctAnswer: Thy congregation which Thou hast purchased of old
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:2 says, 'Remember thy congregation, which thou hast purchased of old; the rod of thine inheritance, which thou hast redeemed.' The psalmist asks God to remember His people.

questions.question: In Psalms 74:4, what do the enemies set up in the midst of God's congregations?
options: Their ensigns for signs
Burning fires
Altars of sacrifice
Walls of defense
questions.correctAnswer: Their ensigns for signs
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:4 states, 'Thine enemies roar in the midst of thy congregations; they set up their ensigns for signs.' The enemies set up ensigns as symbols or banners.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74:6, what tools do the enemies use to break down the carved work?
options: Axes and hammers
Swords and spears
Fire and water
Stones and clubs
questions.correctAnswer: Axes and hammers
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:6 says, 'But now they break down the carved work thereof at once with axes and hammers.' The enemies destroy the sanctuary using these tools.

questions.question: What have the enemies done to the sanctuary as described in Psalms 74:7?
options: Cast fire into it and defiled it
Built a new altar
Blessed it
Protected it from destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Cast fire into it and defiled it
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:7 states, 'They have cast fire into thy sanctuary, they have defiled by casting down the dwelling place of thy name to the ground.' The enemies have burned and defiled the sanctuary.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 74:9 says that the people no longer see their signs or have prophets among them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:9 says, 'We see not our signs: there is no more any prophet: neither is there among us any that knoweth how long.', confirming the absence of signs and prophets.

questions.question: What question is asked in Psalms 74:10 regarding the adversary?
options: How long shall the adversary reproach and blaspheme God's name?
Where is the adversary hiding?
Who is the adversary?
Why did the adversary come?
questions.correctAnswer: How long shall the adversary reproach and blaspheme God's name?
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:10 asks, 'O God, how long shall the adversary reproach? shall the enemy blaspheme thy name for ever?', questioning the duration of the enemy's blasphemy.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74:12, who is described as King and working salvation?
options: God
The enemy
The prophet
The people
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:12 says, 'For God is my King of old, working salvation in the midst of the earth.', describing God as the King who works salvation.

questions.question: Which sea creature's heads did God break by His strength according to Psalms 74:13?
options: Dragons in the waters
Leviathan
Behemoth
Serpents
questions.correctAnswer: Dragons in the waters
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:13 states, 'Thou didst divide the sea by thy strength: thou brakest the heads of the dragons in the waters.', referring to dragons in the waters.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 74:16: 'The day is thine, the night also is thine: thou hast prepared the ______ and the sun.'
options: light
moon
stars
rain
questions.correctAnswer: light
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:16 says, 'The day is thine, the night also is thine: thou hast prepared the light and the sun.', making 'light' the correct word.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 74:19 refer to as 'thy turtledove' whose soul should not be delivered to the wicked?
options: The congregation of the poor
The enemies
The prophets
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation of the poor
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:19 says, 'O deliver not the soul of thy turtledove unto the multitude of the wicked: forget not the congregation of thy poor for ever.', linking the turtledove to the poor congregation.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74:20, what are the dark places of the earth full of?
options: Habitations of cruelty
Light and joy
Peace and love
Temples and altars
questions.correctAnswer: Habitations of cruelty
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:20 says, 'Have respect unto the covenant: for the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of cruelty.', describing the darkness as places of cruelty.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 74:21 asks that the poor and needy return ashamed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:21 states, 'O let not the oppressed return ashamed: let the poor and needy praise thy name.', asking that they not return ashamed but praise God.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 74:22 say reproaches God daily?
options: The foolish man
The prophet
The priest
The king
questions.correctAnswer: The foolish man
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:22 says, 'Arise, O God, plead thine own cause: remember how the foolish man reproacheth thee daily.', identifying the foolish man as the reproacher.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 74:23 mentions that the tumult of those rising against God is decreasing continually.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:23 states, 'the tumult of those that rise up against thee increaseth continually.', meaning the tumult is increasing, not decreasing.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 74 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 74 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of abandonment and anger from God. Based on Psalms 74:1, what biblical truth would you share about God's attitude toward His people?
options: God has cast us off forever and will not forgive us.
God's anger is directed against the sheep of His pasture, but He has not forsaken them permanently.
God does not care about His congregation.
God is indifferent to the sufferings of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger is directed against the sheep of His pasture, but He has not forsaken them permanently.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:1 speaks of God's anger smoking against His sheep but does not indicate a permanent rejection. This teaches us that though God disciplines, He remains the Shepherd of His people. Supporting verses include Psalms 74:2, 74:12-13, and 74:21, which highlight God's ongoing care and power.

questions.question: How does Psalms 74:2 encourage believers to remember God's past faithfulness?
options: By recalling the congregation God purchased and Zion where He dwelt.
By focusing only on future promises.
By ignoring past events and starting anew.
By blaming God for current troubles.
questions.correctAnswer: By recalling the congregation God purchased and Zion where He dwelt.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:2 reminds believers to remember the congregation God purchased and His dwelling on Mount Zion, encouraging trust based on God's historical faithfulness. This supports perseverance and hope in trials (see also Psalms 74:12, 74:18, 74:22).

questions.question: When facing spiritual attacks on the church, what does Psalms 74:4 teach about the nature of the enemy's actions?
options: The enemy roars in the midst of the congregations and sets up their banners as signs.
The enemy is weak and ineffective.
The enemy leaves the congregations alone.
The enemy worships alongside the congregation.
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy roars in the midst of the congregations and sets up their banners as signs.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:4 describes the enemy as aggressive and defiant within God's people, symbolizing opposition believers may face. This encourages vigilance and prayer (cf. Psalms 74:22, 74:23).

questions.question: A church leader observes destruction in the place of worship. Based on Psalms 74:6-7, what biblical perspective should they hold about such trials?
options: Destruction is permanent and means God has abandoned His sanctuary.
Enemies break down and defile the sanctuary, but God’s presence and power remain.
The sanctuary is meaningless and unimportant.
God approves of the destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies break down and defile the sanctuary, but God’s presence and power remain.
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 describe enemies destroying and defiling the sanctuary, teaching that physical destruction can occur, but God's power and kingship (Psalms 74:12) persist, encouraging faith and perseverance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 74:8-9 express the community’s spiritual crisis, and what can this teach us about seeking God during hard times?
options: There are no signs or prophets, leading to uncertainty about the future.
They have many prophets and clear signs.
They are confident about the future without prophets.
They reject all spiritual guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: There are no signs or prophets, leading to uncertainty about the future.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:8-9 reveals a time when God's people see no signs or prophets, symbolizing spiritual desolation. This teaches believers to pray earnestly and trust God’s timing despite uncertainty (see also Psalms 74:10-11).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 74:10, the psalmist believes the enemy's blasphemy against God's name will continue forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:10 questions how long the enemy will blaspheme, implying it is not permanent and calls for God’s intervention. Thus, the expectation is that God will act to end reproach.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 74:12-13, how does the psalmist describe God's sovereignty and power in creation as a source of hope during trials?
options: God is a weak king with no power over nature.
God is the ancient King who divided the sea and defeated mighty creatures.
God has no involvement in the earth.
God is only concerned with human affairs.
questions.correctAnswer: God is the ancient King who divided the sea and defeated mighty creatures.
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize God's mighty acts in creation, such as dividing the sea and breaking the heads of leviathan, illustrating His power to save and protect His people (cf. Psalms 74:14-15).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the apparent triumph of wickedness. What encouragement does Psalms 74:18-19 provide regarding God's protection and remembrance?
options: God forgets the congregation and allows wickedness to prevail.
God remembers the reproach and blasphemy but does not forget His congregation or the vulnerable.
God supports the wicked against the vulnerable.
God ignores the plight of the poor.
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers the reproach and blasphemy but does not forget His congregation or the vulnerable.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:18-19 calls on God to remember the blasphemy of enemies and not forget His people, especially the poor, encouraging trust in God's justice and care.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 74:20 says, 'Have respect unto the _______: for the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of cruelty.'
options: covenant
enemies
prophets
sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: covenant
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:20 refers to God's covenant, urging Him to remember His promises amid widespread cruelty, highlighting the value of faithfulness and divine commitment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 74:21 encourage believers to respond to oppression and poverty within the community?
options: To let the oppressed return ashamed and remain silent.
To allow the poor to be ignored.
To ensure the oppressed are not ashamed and the poor praise God's name.
To focus only on personal prosperity.
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure the oppressed are not ashamed and the poor praise God's name.
questions.explanation: This verse encourages care for the oppressed and needy, promoting dignity and praise to God even in hardship, a model for Christian compassion and stewardship.

questions.question: A believer is praying for justice and vindication. What instruction does Psalms 74:22 give about God's role in defending His cause?
options: God should remain silent and inactive.
God should arise, plead His own cause, and remember daily reproaches.
God should forget the enemies.
God should punish believers.
questions.correctAnswer: God should arise, plead His own cause, and remember daily reproaches.
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:22 calls on God to actively defend His honor against continual insults, teaching believers to trust God's justice and intervention in times of trial.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 74:23 warns that the tumult of those rising against God is decreasing steadily.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:23 states that the tumult of enemies is increasing continually, highlighting the persistent challenges believers face and the need for persistent prayer.

questions.question: How does the imagery of God preparing the day and night in Psalms 74:16 teach believers about God’s sovereignty over daily life?
options: God has no control over natural cycles.
God prepares the light and sun, showing control over day and night.
Day and night happen by chance.
Humans control the natural order.
questions.correctAnswer: God prepares the light and sun, showing control over day and night.
questions.explanation: This verse reminds believers that God orders the natural world, assuring them of His sovereign care over all aspects of life, encouraging trust and contentment.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74:5, what was a man's fame or renown associated with, and how can this be applied to the Christian work ethic?
options: Fame was tied to lifting up axes upon thick trees, symbolizing labor and skill.
Fame came from laziness and idleness.
Fame was irrelevant in biblical times.
Fame was only about wealth accumulation.
questions.correctAnswer: Fame was tied to lifting up axes upon thick trees, symbolizing labor and skill.
questions.explanation: This verse illustrates respect for diligent work, teaching believers to pursue honest labor with integrity and skill as a testimony to God’s provision.

questions.question: How can Psalms 74:14, which speaks of God breaking the heads of leviathan and giving it as food to desert dwellers, encourage believers facing overwhelming trials?
options: It shows God’s power to defeat great obstacles and provide sustenance even in harsh conditions.
It suggests that trials are unbeatable.
It encourages giving up in difficulties.
It implies that God ignores believers in deserts.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s power to defeat great obstacles and provide sustenance even in harsh conditions.
questions.explanation: This verse uses powerful imagery to remind believers that God can conquer formidable enemies and provide for His people, encouraging perseverance and trust.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 74 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 74.

questions.question: In Psalms 74, what is the significance of God being described as the one who 'divided the sea by thy strength' and 'brakest the heads of the dragons in the waters'?
options: It alludes to God’s power over chaos, referencing ancient Near Eastern sea monster myths
It describes a literal historical battle with sea creatures
It symbolizes the division of the Red Sea during the Exodus only
It refers to a future messianic victory in the New Testament
questions.correctAnswer: It alludes to God’s power over chaos, referencing ancient Near Eastern sea monster myths
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:13-14 evoke the ancient Near Eastern motif of God defeating sea monsters like 'leviathan,' symbolizing God's supremacy over chaos, a theme also found in Job 41 and Isaiah 27:1.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 74:4, where enemies 'roar in the midst of thy congregations' and 'set up their ensigns for signs'?
options: Metaphor representing aggressive invasion
Simile comparing enemies to lions
Alliteration emphasizing loudness
Hyperbole indicating exaggeration
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor representing aggressive invasion
questions.explanation: The roaring of enemies is a metaphor for their violent and aggressive presence within God's people, symbolizing destruction and chaos (Psalms 74:4).

questions.question: What historical event is most likely being lamented in Psalms 74, considering the context of enemies burning synagogues and defiling the sanctuary?
options: The destruction of Solomon's Temple by the Babylonians
The Maccabean persecution during the Second Temple period
The destruction of the Tabernacle in the wilderness
The Roman destruction of the Second Temple in 70 AD
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Solomon's Temple by the Babylonians
questions.explanation: The psalm laments the defilement and destruction of the sanctuary, likely referring to the Babylonian destruction of Solomon's Temple, as indicated by references to burning and breaking down (Psalms 74:6-8).

questions.question: In Psalms 74:12, God is referred to as 'my King of old, working salvation in the midst of the earth.' How does this connect with the broader biblical theme of God's kingship?
options: It underscores God's eternal sovereign rule and active saving work throughout history
It refers only to God's kingship over Israel's monarchy
It signifies a temporary reign during the Exodus
It highlights a future kingdom established by the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores God's eternal sovereign rule and active saving work throughout history
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's ancient and ongoing kingship, a theme consistent with passages like Psalm 93 and Daniel 4, portraying God as the eternal sovereign who delivers His people.

questions.question: The phrase 'remember thy congregation, which thou hast purchased of old' in Psalms 74:2 alludes to which covenantal concept?
options: God's covenant relationship with Israel as His possession
The New Covenant established in Jeremiah
The covenant with Noah regarding the rainbow
The Davidic covenant concerning kingship
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenant relationship with Israel as His possession
questions.explanation: The phrase reflects the idea that Israel is God's purchased inheritance, a people set apart by covenant, paralleling themes in Exodus 19:5 and Deuteronomy 7:6.

questions.question: How does the plea in Psalms 74:10, 'O God, how long shall the adversary reproach? shall the enemy blaspheme thy name for ever?' reflect a common lament motif in the Psalms?
options: It expresses the psalmist’s urgent request for divine intervention amid prolonged suffering
It celebrates the enemies’ victory over God’s people
It is a rhetorical question with no expectation of answer
It predicts the final judgment of enemies in the eschaton
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses the psalmist’s urgent request for divine intervention amid prolonged suffering
questions.explanation: This verse typifies the lament form where the psalmist asks God how long the suffering will continue, seeking relief and justice (also seen in Psalms 13:1 and 74:10).

questions.question: In Psalms 74:15-17, God’s creation of natural order is described. What theological purpose does this section serve within the psalm’s lament?
options: To remind the audience of God’s sovereign power over all creation, contrasting the current destruction
To shift focus from human sin to natural phenomena
To imply that nature causes the temple’s destruction
To establish a mythological account of the cosmos
questions.correctAnswer: To remind the audience of God’s sovereign power over all creation, contrasting the current destruction
questions.explanation: By highlighting God’s control over day, night, rivers, and seasons, the psalmist emphasizes God's ability to restore order amid the temple’s ruin (Psalms 74:15-17).

questions.question: Which Hebrew word translated as 'leviathan' in Psalms 74:14 carries significance in ancient Near Eastern mythology and biblical theology?
options: It represents a mythic sea monster symbolizing chaos defeated by God
It is a term for a large fish used in sacrificial rituals
It signifies a king of Israel in poetic form
It denotes a type of fortress or stronghold
questions.correctAnswer: It represents a mythic sea monster symbolizing chaos defeated by God
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'leviathan' refers to a legendary sea monster, representing chaos, whose defeat by God is a common motif illustrating divine sovereignty (Psalms 74:14; Job 41).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 74:19, the 'turtledove' is a metaphor for God's vulnerable people whom He is urged to protect.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The 'turtledove' symbolically represents the vulnerable or innocent people of God, emphasizing the psalmist’s plea for their protection (Psalms 74:19).

questions.question: Psalms 74:11 asks, 'Why withdrawest thou thy hand, even thy right hand? pluck it out of thy bosom.' What is the significance of the 'right hand' in biblical symbolism here?
options: The right hand symbolizes God's power and favor withheld
It refers to the literal hand of a human king
It indicates a ritual gesture of blessing
It is a metaphor for the day of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The right hand symbolizes God's power and favor withheld
questions.explanation: The 'right hand' commonly symbolizes God’s power and support; asking why it is withdrawn expresses a sense of divine abandonment (Psalms 74:11; Exodus 15:6).

questions.question: The phrase in Psalms 74:20, 'for the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of cruelty,' exemplifies which literary device?
options: Metonymy representing evil in hidden places
Simile comparing darkness to cruelty
Personification of evil as a dwelling
Hyperbole emphasizing the extent of wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: Personification of evil as a dwelling
questions.explanation: The verse personifies 'dark places' as being filled with ‘habitations of cruelty,’ attributing to evil a tangible dwelling place to emphasize its pervasiveness (Psalms 74:20).

questions.question: How does the structural placement of the plea 'Arise, O God, plead thine own cause' in Psalms 74:22 function within the psalm’s overall literary form?
options: It serves as a climactic call to divine justice after recounting suffering
It introduces the lament section at the beginning
It concludes the psalm with a hymn of praise
It interrupts the narrative with a historical flashback
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a climactic call to divine justice after recounting suffering
questions.explanation: The verse acts as a turning point, a direct appeal to God to act amidst ongoing reproach, highlighting a chiastic structure common in laments (Psalms 74:22).

questions.question: In the context of Psalms 74, what does the 'rod of thine inheritance' in verse 2 symbolize?
options: God’s authority and rule over His chosen people
A literal shepherd’s staff used in temple rituals
A reference to the king’s scepter in Jerusalem
A symbol of divine punishment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s authority and rule over His chosen people
questions.explanation: The 'rod' is a symbol of divine authority and guidance over Israel, emphasizing the covenantal relationship and God’s protection (Psalms 74:2; Micah 6:9).

questions.question: What theological theme does the lament over the absence of prophets and signs in Psalms 74:9 highlight?
options: The crisis of divine revelation and guidance during national calamity
The rejection of prophecy in the New Testament
The fulfillment of all prophecy in the past
The end of miracles in the post-exilic period
questions.correctAnswer: The crisis of divine revelation and guidance during national calamity
questions.explanation: The psalmist expresses distress over the lack of prophetic guidance and visible signs from God, symbolizing a spiritual desolation during exile or destruction (Psalms 74:9).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 74 was written by Asaph as a communal lament to help the post-exilic community understand the destruction of the sanctuary and God’s continued sovereignty.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalm is attributed to Asaph and functions as a communal lament, addressing the destruction of the sanctuary and affirming God’s enduring kingship, relevant to post-exilic reflection (Psalms 74 heading and content).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 74 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 74 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74, what is the primary reason the psalmist asks God why He has cast them off?
options: Because God's anger smokes against the sheep of His pasture
Because they have sinned grievously
Because the enemy has destroyed the sanctuary
Because no prophet remains among them
questions.correctAnswer: Because God's anger smokes against the sheep of His pasture
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:1 directly expresses the psalmist's anguish over God's anger against His people, depicted as the sheep of His pasture. This theme of God's protective care for His flock is consistent with John 10:11, Ezekiel 34:11-16, Isaiah 40:11, and Hebrews 13:20.

questions.question: In Psalms 74, what does the psalmist urge God to remember?
options: Thy congregation which Thou hast purchased of old
The temple built by Solomon
The destruction of Babylon
The exile in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Thy congregation which Thou hast purchased of old
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls God to remember His purchased congregation and the inheritance on Mount Zion (Psalm 74:2). This recalls God's covenant people, as in Exodus 19:5, Deuteronomy 32:9, and Hebrews 12:22, emphasizing God's faithfulness to His covenant.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 74 to describe God's people?
options: Sheep of His pasture
Vine in the vineyard
Olive tree branches
Living stones
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep of His pasture
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:1 uses the metaphor of sheep to describe God's people, highlighting His role as a shepherd. This metaphor is consistent with passages like John 10:14, Psalm 23, and Ezekiel 34:12.

questions.question: How does Psalms 74 describe the enemy's actions in the sanctuary?
options: They break down the carved work with axes and hammers
They peacefully worship alongside the congregation
They build new altars for God
They sing hymns of praise
questions.correctAnswer: They break down the carved work with axes and hammers
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:6 describes the enemies violently destroying the sanctuary's carved work using axes and hammers. This reflects the profaning and desecration of holy places, as seen in Daniel 11:31 and 2 Maccabees 6:6.

questions.question: What has the enemy done to the synagogues of God, according to Psalms 74?
options: Burned them up
Blessed them
Rebuilt them
Ignored them
questions.correctAnswer: Burned them up
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:8 states that the enemy has burned up all the synagogues of God, illustrating the destruction of places of worship. This is consistent with accounts of temple destruction in 2 Chronicles 36:19 and Jeremiah 52:13.

questions.question: What lament does the psalmist express about prophetic guidance in Psalms 74?
options: There is no more any prophet
Prophets have multiplied greatly
Prophets are speaking clearly
Prophets are leading the people well
questions.correctAnswer: There is no more any prophet
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:9 laments the absence of prophets and signs, highlighting a spiritual crisis and the lack of divine revelation. This resonates with Jeremiah 14:14 and Hosea 4:6 about the failure of prophetic guidance.

questions.question: According to Psalms 74, what divine act demonstrates God's power over chaos and evil?
options: Dividing the sea and breaking the heads of the dragons
Building a great tower
Sending a mighty army
Making a covenant with kings
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing the sea and breaking the heads of the dragons
questions.explanation: Psalms 74:13-14 recount God's mighty works over the sea and Leviathan, symbolizing His sovereignty over chaos and evil, similar to Job 41, Isaiah 27:1, and Revelation 20:2 where God's power over chaotic forces is affirmed.

questions.question: What does Psalms 74 say God prepared that indicates His control over creation?
options: The light and the sun
The mountains and rivers
The animals and birds
The heavens and stars
questions.correctAnswer: The light and the sun
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:16 states God prepared the light and the sun, affirming His sovereign control over day and night, paralleling Genesis 1:14-19, Jeremiah 31:35, and John 1:4-5.

questions.question: What plea does the psalmist make regarding the 'turtledove' in Psalms 74?
options: Do not deliver its soul to the multitude of the wicked
Offer it as a sacrifice to God
Send it to the nations
Let it fly freely
questions.correctAnswer: Do not deliver its soul to the multitude of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:19 pleads for God to protect the 'turtledove,' symbolizing the vulnerable congregation, from the wicked. This reflects God's care for His people seen in Psalm 55:6, Matthew 10:29, and Isaiah 38:14.

questions.question: In Psalms 74, what is the psalmist's request concerning the covenant?
options: Have respect unto the covenant
Break the covenant for justice
Forget the covenant made in old times
Create a new covenant immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Have respect unto the covenant
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:20 appeals to God's faithfulness to His covenant despite the darkness and cruelty prevailing, echoing themes from Exodus 34:6-7, 2 Corinthians 1:20, and Hebrews 8:10 about God's unchanging covenant promises.

questions.question: How does Psalms 74 describe the enemies' attitude toward God's name?
options: They blaspheme and reproach it continually
They revere it with respect
They are indifferent to it
They keep it sacred
questions.correctAnswer: They blaspheme and reproach it continually
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:10,18,22 highlights the enemies' continual blasphemy and reproach against God's name, emphasizing the spiritual conflict consistent with Romans 2:24 and John 15:25 about opposition to God's reputation.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do in response to the reproach of the foolish?
options: Arise and plead thine own cause
Remain silent forever
Accept their reproach
Hide from the enemy
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and plead thine own cause
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:22 calls for God to act and defend His honor against the foolish, reflecting the biblical motif of God as judge and defender in Isaiah 1:17, Psalm 35:1, and Revelation 6:10.

questions.question: What natural phenomena does Psalms 74 attribute to God's creative power?
options: Dividing the sea, cleaving fountains, setting borders of the earth
Creating mountains and valleys
Forming animals and birds
Making the stars and moon
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing the sea, cleaving fountains, setting borders of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalm 74:13,15,17 describe God's acts of dividing the sea, cleaving fountains, and setting earth’s borders, demonstrating His sovereignty over nature, consistent with Genesis 1, Job 38, and Jeremiah 5:22.

questions.question: What does the psalmist request regarding the oppressed in Psalms 74?
options: Let them not return ashamed
Let them be forgotten
Let them be punished
Let them be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: Let them not return ashamed
